Title: Why I believe in AGI (again) - Alexey Guzey
Description:
I keep getting asked why I believe in AGI again.
First, I‚Äôm now convinced that ChatGPT understands what it reads. Second, reasoning models persuade me that ChatGPT is creative. Third, ChatGPT summarizes texts extremely well, which I believe to be a robust measure of intelligence.
At the same time, I don‚Äôt believe in ‚Äúgeneral intelligence‚Äù (I don‚Äôt consider myself one) and so I don‚Äôt believe the idea of ‚ÄúAGI‚Äù is very meaningful.
Finally, AI products now pay for AGI ‚Ä¶

Title: Do LLMs identify fonts?
Description:
Spoiler: not really
dafont.com is a wonderful website that contains a large collection of fonts. It‚Äôs more comprehensive and esoteric than Google Fonts. One of its features is a forum where users can ask for help identifying fonts ‚Äì check out this poor fellow who‚Äôs been waiting for over two years and bumped his thread. I thought it would be interesting to see if an LLM could do this task, so I scraped the forum and set up a benchmark.

Title: How to sell open source technology to the government
Description: As governments legalize cannabis, they create billion-dollar industries. A trade-off for this massive economic value-add is the need for regulatory tracking technology. This technology is typically dominated by large, proprietary players. In commercial cannabis, competitors come from pharmaceuticals and private equity.

Title: Avoid IaaS Lock-In With a SAML Proxy
Description:
TL;DR Adopting an Infrastructure As A Service (IaaS) provider can save huge
time and effort when implementing a B2B SaaS product, but it can also result in
deep lock-in with the provider. I explain how deploying a SAML Proxy can
mitigate this, and provide a case study of migrating hundreds of customers from
one IaaS provider to a competitor instantly and with near zero disruption. I
also introduce my new open source SAML
Proxy, a fully functional demo that
you can try out yourself and modify for your own custom scenarios.
